By HEATHER KNIGHT
and ALEXANDRA BERZON
HHigh above an arena packed
with Democratic delegates in Chi-
cago last week, video introduced

"Behind me is where it all be--
gan," said her childhood friend,

story home where Ms. Harris
grew up in a small apartment
above a nursery school.
But where was that exactly?
The screen simply read "East
Bay," as in the eastern section of
the San Francisco Bay Area that
sprawls over 1,400 square miles
and is home to nearly three mil-
lion people. Ms. Harris called the
area just "he bay" in her speech
on Thursday night. Other speak-

Israel and Hezbollah Claim Victories ofSorts

By ISABEL KERSHNER JERUSALEM-For weeks,
sraelis have waited in trepidation for a major attack by Hezbollah in retaliation for Is rael's assassination of a senior
commander of the Lebanese group in Beirut last month, amid widespread fears that a cross-
border escalation could spiral
into an all-out regional war. But much of Israel woke up o Sunday to find that at least for the immediate term, the long-
dreaded attack appeared to be dreaded attack appeared to be
over almost before it started Both Israel and Hezbollah quickly claimed victories of
sorts: Israel for its preda pre-emptive strikes against wh the military said were thousands of Hezbollah's rocket launcher and Hezbollah for Lebanon; firing of barrages of rockets and drones at northern Israel, which the israelil milit
By breakfast time, the two
sides were employing the lat sides were employing the lan-
guage of containment. Hezbollah announced that it
had completed the "first state had completed the "first stage"
its attack to avenge the assassi nation of the senior commande Fuad Shukr, and appeared to be calling it a day, at least for now.

according to a statement from Mr. Gallant's office. Hezbollah's leader, Hassan

served the right to respond later date.

Fears Grow That Conflict With Lebanon Could
Spread in Region

This article is by Aaron Boxer-
man, Isabel Kershner and Euan Ward.
JERUSALEM - Amid fears of an all-out war between Israel and
Hezbollah forces in Lebanon, the wo sides on Sunday mounted the biggest round of cross-border
strikes since the war in Gaza be gan, with Israel bombing dozens of sites in a pre-emptive attack and Hezbollah launching hundreds of rockets and drones. peared to de-escalate, at least temporarily, but signaled that the violence and dangerous tensions
could continue. Hezbollah said its operation, vengeance for the Iscomil assassination of a senio
commander, had "finished for the day" but left open the possibility of Arther action. Prime Minister
Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said that "what happened today is not the final word."
